results.title: Vampire princess Miyu 4 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Miyu Production Committee, Joel Baral and Toshihiro Hirano
results.brief_description: Shinma are supernatural beings that devour the hearts of men and lead them to ruin. Long ago they were sealed in the Dark World. However, there are stray Shinma that live secretly in the human world. They lurk in the division between night and day. The Guardian who sends the stray Shinma back to the Dark World is the beautiful vampire, Miyu. No-one knows her true face. The childlike vampire and her faithful demon servant Larva continue to obliterate rampant Shinma from the human realm in episodes 12 to 16 of the Vampire Princess Miyu television series. Diverging slightly from the conventions set in the original animated video, the stories on this compilation explore the recurrent themes of karmic fate and the price of immortality although they retain Kenji Kawai’s ambient music and the dark, gothic feel, synonymous with this series. In “Garden of the crying reeds,” a lonely young man searching for his lost cat gets more than he bargained for when he agrees to do a favour for a stunning woman living amidst the ruins of a Western style mansion. In “Light of the sea (part one),” Miyu becomes distressed when Larva disappears after being charmed away from her side by an unknown force, with the only clues to his whereabouts linked to a pair of local shinma who have fallen in love. Her quest to find her protector-servant is both helped and hindered by the sudden appearance of fellow guardian and sworn enemy, Reiha. In “Light of the sea (part two),” the first meeting between Larva and Miyu is revealed in flashback, setting the scene for the inevitable showdown to follow. In “Dream of the mermaid,” a young man believes he has found a soul mate when he encounters an unhappy mermaid at the city aquarium, unwilling to believe that she is a shinma. In “Woman priest,” Yui-Li, a Chinese priestess and do-shi martial arts expert arrives in Japan, determined to hunt down and vanquish the shinma who destroyed those she loved.

results.title: Vampire Princess Miyu
results.creator_credit: Manga Entertainment, Yasushi Nomura, Toru Miura, Eri Tsukamoto and Toshihiro Hirano
results.brief_description: Eerie exploits of a childlike vampire, Princess Miyu, who travels between two worlds - the human realm and and a strange underworld of demon gods and lost souls. Two chapters of her story are included in this videocassette. In ‘Capital of mystery’ the search is on to find the evil force which is killing the women of Kyoto. Princess Miyu in the second episode ‘Puppet festival’ must defeat the evil vampire Ranka whose kiss turns mortals into puppets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Manga Entertainment, Yasushi Nomura, Toru Miura, Eri Tsukamoto and Toshihiro Hirano

results.title: Vampire myths
results.brief_description: This documentary examines the contemporary fascination with vampirism and vampire culture. Bram Stoker’s famous novel, Dracula, has spawned a multitude of fictions since it’s debut in 1897. This documentary examines the contemporary fascination with this literary vision of vampirism, and focuses on the subculture that has evolved around it, questioning whether it reflects a desire for immortality, or if it is simply another way of making contact with the darker side of humanity. In an effort to understand the appeal of this movement, the documentary delves into the history of Vlad Tsepes (Dracul), the 15th century warrior-prince whom Stoker based the character of Dracula upon. To explore this phenomenon further, there are interviews with Nicholas Strathloch, who claims to come from a long line of vampires and drinks human blood, Kathy and Dale McKinley, who claim to be able to channel the spirit of Vlad Tsepes, and Catrina Coffin, who lives like a vampire. Opinions are also sought from a diverse array of people including a theologian, a psychiatrist, an author, a member of the Transylvanian Society of Dracula, a hypnotist and a psychic.

results.title: Vampire lovers
results.creator_credit: Hammer Films, American International Pictures (AIP), Harry Fine, Michael Style and Roy Baker
results.brief_description: In 18th century Styria, Austria, a series of mysterious deaths causes superstitious villagers to suspect vampires abound. Meanwhile General Spielsdorf (Peter Cushing) is hosting a ball when a mysterious young woman Marcilla (Ingrid Pitt) arrives and subsequently becomes a guest at his home. Marcilla seduces the general’s beautiful young daughter, who dies after being beset by nightmares. Shortly after Marcilla turns up in several other estates (under various names) seeking out nubile young women to satiate her thirst for blood. The General and Baron Hartog gather a posse of men, to ferret out and exterminate the vampire. This version of J. Sheridan Le Fanu’s story “Carmilla” plays out as a mildly terrifying erotic thriller, produced by Hammer, the classic British production house, at a time when they were tapping into the zeitgeist of the times by presenting excessive nudity within the auspices of the horror genre. At times the film is genuinely spooky, but much of the film is lavishly devoted to displaying milky white bosoms heaving out of trussed up dresses. This film is part of a trilogy of Hammer lesbian/vampire films that incudes “Lust for a vampire” (1971) and “Twins of evil” (1972).

results.title: Vampire hunter D: bloodlust [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Urban Vision Entertainment, Film Line International, Mata Yamamoto, Masao Maruyama, Taka Nagasawa and Yoshiaki Kawajiri
results.brief_description: In this animated horror movie, set in a menacing distant future where the dead haunt the living, a deadly vampire kidnaps a beautiful human woman. Her distraught family offer a huge reward for her rescue - dead or alive. One bounty hunter, Dunpeal, a half-human, half-vampire being, at war with himself, tortured and alone, is hired to retrieve the girl. But a rival group of rescuers, the Marcus siblings, resent Dunpeal’s presence, and plan to use him in order to collect the loot. In his quest, D faces many nasty encounters with murderous semi-human creatures, including a werewolf, a shape-shifter, a phantom queen, and a subculture of human-hating monsters. In Vampire Hunter D: Bloodlust”, the sequel to “Vampire hunter D (1985), the future has the aesthetic of a dystopic, medieval nightmare but the animation is far more sophisticated than in the original. Director Yoshiaki Kawajiri (Wicked City, Animatrix) keeps the action exciting, even if the characterisations are simplistic, and the violent gory animatronics are awe-inspiring in scope, embodying all the qualities of gothic, bloody combat, whilst harking to the model of the eternal outsider, moody and disliked, shunned by society and feared by his enemies.

results.title: Value analysis
results.creator_credit: Basic Films, Leon Clore and Sam Napier-Bell
results.brief_description: Value analysis is a disciplined approach to cost reduction by the systematic examination and appraisal of the product and its components. Introduced in an engineering company, it emphasises the importance of team approach and describes in detail the various stages of a value analysis investigation. Some convincing examples of reduction in costs through value analysis.

results.title: Valleys and people
results.creator_credit: Summit Film Productions and Douglas M. Robinson
results.brief_description: A story of the accomplishments of Ontario’s Conservation authorities Branch, Department of Energy and Resources Management in Canada. Looks at how a conservation authority works and emphasises the need to retain the balance of nature.

results.title: Valley town
results.creator_credit: Educational Film Institute, New York University and Willard Van Dyke
results.brief_description: The story of how machines made a “boom” town with factories running at top speed, stores crowded with shoppers, money flowing freely - and of how more machines broke it. Considers the problem of capable workers thrown out of jobs because of high-speed machinery. Gives an idea of what this does to the human spirit and of the effect on a family. Finally offers as one solution the constant training of adults to keep them abreast of new developments ready for new and better jobs. Narrated by Ray Collins.

results.title: Valley of the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of the Interior. Film Division and Maslyn Williams
results.brief_description: Follows the Yarra River from its source in the mountains to the busy port where it joins Port Phillip Bay. Stresses the importance of the Yarra in the supply of water for Melbourne. Shows farmlands and towns, landscapes and scenery along the river as it goes through to Melbourne.

results.title: Valley of the Murray River. Part 3
results.brief_description: In this final film of a three-part series, the Murray River is followed to the more northern and drier area where the annual rainfall ranges from ten to eighteen inches. This area is known as the Mallee and is a region of dry, red soil and stunted growth. Cleared and irrigated it is an area of productive farmlands and well-kept orchards, with its eastern section producing much of Victoria’s wheat. The irrigation upon which much of this district depends is indicated and the main agricultural pursuits illustrated. These include the citrus and vine-growin areas of Robinvale, Mildura, Merbein and Red Cliffs. The film then follows the river into South Australia and illustrates the industries and activities of the people who depend upon the waters of the river for their livelihood. Little water from the Murray enters the sea. In summer it irrigates the land; in winter it fills the storages. The film concludes with scenes at the river’s mouth at Lake Alexandrina. Commentary by Roger Climpson.
